titleStmt.title: J.M. Synge's Riders to the Sea: An Electronic Edition

availability.p: Text of the play, having been published prior to 1922, is in the public domain in the United States. You are free to re-use, and build upon, the encoded text as you wish.

sourceDesc.bibl: Text taken from the version of the play published in Samhain: An Occasional Review in September, 1903 (pp. 25-33).

normalization.p: Speaker names have been converted from all caps, periods within the speaker element and the em dashes between the speaker name and text have not been transcribed; em dashes in the text are rendered as -- .

div.stage: SCENE. -- Island off the West of Ireland. Cottage kitchen, with nets, oil-skins, spinning whell, some new boards standing by the wall, etc. Cathleen, a girl of about twenty, finishes kneading cake, and puts it down in the pot-oven by the fire; then wipes her hands, and begins to spin at the wheel. Nora, a young girl, puts her head in at the door.

sp.speaker: Nora
sp.p: Where is she?

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: She's lying down; God help her, and maybe sleeping, if she's able.

div.stage: Nora comes in softly, and takes a bundle from under her shawl.

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: What is it you have?

sp.speaker: Nora
sp.p: The young priest is after bringing them. It's a shirt and a plain stocking were got off a drowned man in Donegal.

div.stage: (Cathleen stops her wheel with a sudden movement, and leans out to listen).

sp.speaker: Nora
sp.p: We're to find out if it's Michael's they are, some time herself will be down looking by the sea.

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: How would they be Michael's, Nora. How would he go the length of that way to the far north?

sp.speaker: Nora
sp.p: The young priest says he's known the like of it. . . "If it's Michael's they are," says he, "you can tell herself he's got a clean burial by the grace of God, and if they're not his let no one say a word about them, for she'll be getting her death," says he, "with crying and lamenting."
sp.stage: The door which Nora half closed behind her is blown open by a gust of wind.)

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: Did you ask him would he stop Bartley going this day to Connemara?

sp.speaker: Nora
sp.p: "I won't stop him," says he, "but let you not be afraid. Herself does be saying prayers half through the night, and the Almighty God won't leave her destitute," says he, "with no son living."

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: Is the sea bad by the white rocks, Nora?

sp.speaker: Nora
sp.p: Middling bad, God help us. There's a great roaring in the west, and it's worse it'll be getting when the tide's turned to the wind. (She goes over to the table with the bundle)Shall I open it now?

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: Maybe she'd wake up on us, and come in before we'd done. (Coming to the table)It's a long time we'll be, and the two of us crying.

sp.speaker: Nora
sp.stage: (Goes to the inner door and listens).
sp.p: She's moving about on the bed. She'll be coming in a minute.

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: Give me the ladder, and I'll put them up in the turf-loft, the way she won't know of them at all, and maybe when the tide turns she'll be going down to see would he be floating from the east.

div.stage: (They put the ladder against the gable of the chimney, and Cathleen goes up under the thatch with the bundle in her hand. Maurya, the old woman, comes from the inner room).

sp.speaker: Maurya
sp.stage: (looking up at Cathleen and speaking querulously).
sp.p: Isn't it turf enough you have for this day and evening?

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: There's a cake baking at the fire for a short space (throwing down turf), and Bartley will want it when the tide turns if he goes to Connemara.

div.stage: (Nora picks up the turf and puts it round the pot-oven).

sp.speaker: Maurya
sp.stage: (sitting down on a stool at the fire).
sp.p: He won't go this day with the wind rising from the south and west. He won't go this day, for the young priest will stop him surely.

sp.speaker: Nora
sp.p: He'll not stop him, mother, and I heard Eamon Simon and Stephen Pheety and Colum Shawn saying he would go.

sp.speaker: Maurya
sp.p: Where is he itself?

sp.speaker: Nora
sp.p: He went down to see would there be another boat sailing in the week, and I'm thinking it won't be long till he's here now, for the tide's turning at the green head, and the hooker's tacking from the east.

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: I hear someone passing the big stones.

sp.speaker: Nora
sp.p: He's coming now, and he is in a hurry.

sp.speaker: Bartley
sp.stage: (comes in and looks round the room.
sp.p: Where is the bit of new rope, Cathleen, was bought in Connemara?

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: Give it to him, Nora; it's on a nail by the white boards. I hung it up this morning, for the pig with the black feet was eating it.

sp.speaker: Nora
sp.p: Is that it, Bartley?

sp.speaker: Maurya
sp.p: You'ld do right to leave that rope, Bartley, hanging by the boards. (Bartley takes the rope.)It will be wanting in this place, I'm telling you, if Michael is washed up to-morrow morning, or the next morning, or any morning of the week, for it's a deep grave we'll make him by the grace of God.

sp.speaker: Bartley
sp.p:
I've no halter the way I can ride down on the mare, and I must go now quickly. This is the one
boat going for two weeks or beyond it, and the fair will be a good fair I heard them saying below.

sp.speaker: Maurya
sp.p: It a hard thing they'll be saying below if the body is washed up and there's no man in it to make the coffin, and I after giving a big price for the finest white boards you'ld find in Connemara.

div.stage: (She looks round at the boards).

sp.speaker: Bartley
sp.p: How would it be washed up, and we after looking each day for nine days, and a strong wind blowing a while back from the west and south?

sp.speaker: Maurya
sp.p: If it isn't found itself, that wind is raising the sea, and there was a star up against the moon, and it rising in the night. If it was a hundred horses, or a thousand horses you had itself, what is the price of a thousand horses against a son where there is one son only?

sp.speaker: Bartley
sp.p: Let you go down each day, and see the sheep aren't jumping in on the rye, and if the jobber comes you can sell the pig with the black feet if there is a good price going.

sp.speaker: Maurya
sp.p: How would the like of her get a good price for a pig?

sp.speaker: Bartley
sp.p: If the west wind holds with the last bit of the moon let you and Nora get up weed enough for another cock for the kelp. . . . It's hard set we'll be from this day with no one in it but one man to work.

sp.speaker: Maurya
sp.p: It's hard set we'll be surely the day you're drown'd with the rest. What way will I live and the girls with me, and I an old woman looking for the grave?

div.stage: (Bartley lays down the halter; takes off his old coat, and puts on a newer one of the same flannel).

sp.speaker: Bartley
sp.p: Is she coming to the pier?

sp.speaker: Nora
sp.p: She's passing the green head and letting fall her sails.

sp.speaker: Bartley
sp.p: I'll have half an hour to go down, and you'll see me coming again in two days, or in three days, or maybe in four days if the wind is bad. . . .

sp.speaker: Maurya
sp.stage: (turning round to the fire, and putting her shawl over her head).
sp.p: Isn't it a hard and cruel man won't hear a word from an old woman, and she holding him from the sea?

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: It's the life of a young man to be going on the sea, and who would listen to an old woman with one thing and she saying it over?

sp.speaker: Bartley
sp.p: I must go now quickly. I'll ride down on the red mare, and the gray pony 'll run behind me. . . The blessing of God on you.

sp.speaker: Maurya
sp.stage: (crying out as he is in the door).
sp.p: He's gone now, God spare us, and we'll not see him again. He's gone now and when the black night is falling I'll have no son left me in the world.

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p:
Why wouldn't you give him your blessing and he looking
round in the door? Isn't it sorrow enough is on everyone in this house without your sending him out with an unlucky word behind him, and a hard word in his ear?

div.stage: (Maurya takes up the tongs and begins raking the fire aimlessly without looking round.)

sp.speaker: Nora
sp.p: You're taking away the turf from the cake.

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: The Son of God forgive us, Nora, we're after forgetting his bit of bread.

sp.speaker: Nora
sp.p: And it's destroyed he'll be going till dark night, and he after eating nothing since the sun went up.

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.stage: (turning the cake out of the oven).
sp.p: It's destroyed he'll be, surely. . . . There's no sense left on any person in a house where an old woman will be talking forever.

div.stage: (Maurya sways herself on her stool.)

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.stage: cuts off some of the bread and rolls it in a cloth; to Maurya
sp.p: Let you go down now to the spring well and give him this and he passing. You'll see him then and the dark word will be broken, and you can say "God speed you," the way he'll be easy in his mind.

sp.speaker: Maurya
sp.p: Will I be in it as soon as himself?

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: If you go now quickly.

sp.speaker: Maurya
sp.p: It's hard set I am to walk.

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: Give her the stick, Nora, or maybe she'll slip on the big stones.

sp.speaker: Nora
sp.p: What stick?

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: The stick Michael brought from Connemara.

sp.speaker: Maurya
sp.p: In the big world the old people do be leaving things after them for their sons and children, but in this place it is the young men do be leaving things behind for them that do be old.

div.stage: (Nora goes over to the ladder.)

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: Wait, Nora, maybe she'd turn back quickly. She's that sorry, God help her, you wouldn't know the thing she'd do.

sp.speaker: Nora
sp.p: Is she gone round by the bush?

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: She's gone now. Throw it down quickly, for the Lord knows when she'll be out of it again.

sp.speaker: Nora
sp.p: The young priest said he'd be passing to-morrow, and we might go down and speak to him below if it's Michael's they are surely.

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: Did he say what way they were found?

sp.speaker: Nora
sp.p: "There were two men," says he, "and they rowing round with poteen before the cocks crowed, and the oar of one of them caught the body and they passing the black cliffs of the north."

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p:
Give me a knife, Nora, the
string's perished with the salt water, and there's a black knot on it you wouldn't loosen in a week.

sp.speaker: Nora
sp.p: I've heard tell it was a long way to Donegal.

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: It is surely. There was a man in here a while ago -- the man sold us that knife -- and he said if you set off walking from the rocks beyond it would be in seven days you'd be in Donegal.

sp.speaker: Nora
sp.p: And what time would a man take and he floating?

div.stage: (Cathleen opens the bundle and takes out a bit of a shirt and a stocking. They look at them eagerly).

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: The Lord spares us, Nora; isn't is a queer hard thing to say if it's his they are surely?

sp.speaker: Nora
sp.p: I'll get his shirt off the hook the way we can put the one flannel on the other. (She looks through some clothes hanging in the corner). It's not with them, Cathleen, and where will it be?

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: I'm thinking Bartley put it on him in the morning, for his own shirt was heavy with the salt in it (pointing to the corner). There's a bit of a sleeve was of the same stuff. Give me that and it will do.

div.stage: (Nora brings it to her and they compare the flannel).

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: It's the same stuff, Nora; but if it is itself, aren't there great rolls of it in the shops of Galway, and isn't it many another man may have a shirt of it as well as Michael himself?

sp.speaker: Nora
sp.stage: (who has taken up the stocking and counted the stitches, crying out).
sp.p: It's Michael, Cathleen, it's Michael; God spare his soul, and what will herself say when she hears this story and Bartley on the sea?

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: It's a plain stocking.

sp.speaker: Nora
sp.p: It's the second one of the third pair I knitted, and I put up threescore stitches, and I dropped four of them.

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: It's that number is in it. (Crying out) Ah, Nora, isn't it a bitter thing to think of him floating that way to the far north, and no one to keen him but the black hags that do be flying on the sea?

sp.speaker: Nora
sp.stage: swinging herself half round, and throwing out her arm on the clothes).
sp.p: And isn't it a pitiful thing when there is nothing left of a man who was a great rower and fisher, but a bit of an old shirt and a plain stocking?

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: Tell me is herself coming, Nora. I hear a little sound on the path.

sp.speaker: Nora
sp.p: She is, Cathleen. She's coming up to the door.

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: Put these things away before she'll come in. Maybe it's easier she'll be after giving her blessing to Bartley, and we wont let on we've heard anything the time he's on the sea.

sp.speaker: Nora
sp.p: We'll put them here in the corner (they put them into a hole in the chimney corner. Cathleen goes back to the spinning-wheel).

sp.speaker: Nora
sp.p: Will she see it was crying I was?

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: Keep your back to the door the way the light 'll not be on you.

div.stage: [Nora sits down at the chimney corner, with her back to the door. Maurya comes in very slowly, without looking at the girls, and goes over to her stool at the other side of the fire. The cloth with the bread is still in her hand. The girls look at each other, and Nora points to the bundle of bread.]

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: You didn't give him his bit of bread?

div.stage: [Maurya begins to keen softly, without turning round.]

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: Did you see him riding down?

div.stage: [Maurya goes on keening.]

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: God forgive you; isn't it a better thing to raise your voice and tell what you've seen, than to be making lamentation for a thing that's done? Did you see Bartley, I'm saying to you.

sp.speaker: Maurya
sp.p: My heart's broken from this day.

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: Did you see Bartley?

sp.speaker: Maurya
sp.p: I seen the fearfulest thing.

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: God forgive you; he's riding the mare now over the green head, and the gray pony behind him.

sp.speaker: Maurya
sp.stage: (starts, so that her shawl falls back from her head and shows her white tossed hair. With a frightened voice).
sp.p: The gray pony behind him . . .

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: What is it ails you, at all?

sp.speaker: Maurya
sp.p: I’ve seen the fearfulest thing any person has seen, since the day Bride Dara saw the dead man with the child in his arms.

sp.speaker: Cathleen and Nora
sp.p: Uah.

div.stage: [They crouch down in front of the old woman at the ﬁre.]

sp.speaker: Nora
sp.p: Tell us what it is you seen.

sp.speaker: Maurya.
sp.p: I went down to the spring well, and I stood there saying a prayer to myself. Then Bartley came along, and he riding on the red mare with the gray pony behind him (she puts up her hands, as if to hide something from her eyes). The Son of God spare us, Nora.

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: What is it you seen?

sp.speaker: Maurya
sp.p: I seen Michael himself.

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: You did not, mother; it wasn't Michael you seen, for his body is after being found in the far north, and he's got a clean burial by the grace of God.

sp.speaker: Maurya
sp.p:
I'm after seeing him this day, and he riding and galloping. Bartley came first on the red mare; and I tried to say "God speed you," but something choked the words in my throat. He went by quickly; and "the blessing of God on you," says he, and I could say nothing. I looked up then, and I crying, at the gray pony, and
there was Michael upon it -- with ﬁne clothes on him, and new shoes on his feet.

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: It's destroyed we are from this day. It's destroyed, surely.

sp.speaker: Nora
sp.p: Didn't the young priest say the Almighty God wont leave her destitute with no son living?

sp.speaker: Maurya
sp.p: It's little the like of him knows of the sea. . . Bartley will be lost now, and let you call in Eamon and make me a good cofﬁn out of the white boards, for I wont live after them. I've had a husband, and a husband's father, and six sons in this house -- six ﬁne men, though it was a hard birth I had with everyone of them and they coming to the world -- and there were some of them were found and some of them were not found, but they're gone now the lot of them. . . There were Stephen, and Shawn, were lost in the great wind, and found after in the Bay of Gregory of the Golden Mouth, and carried up the two of them on one plank, and in by that door.

div.stage: (She pauses for a moment, the girls start as if they heard something through the door that is half open behind them.)

sp.speaker: Nora
sp.p: Did you hear that, Cathleen? Did you hear a noise in the North-East?

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: There's some one after crying out by the seashore.

sp.speaker: Maurya
sp.p: There was Sheamus and his father, and his own father again, were lost in a dark night, and not a stick or sign was seen of them when the sun went up. . . There was Patch after was drowned out of a curagh that turned over. I was sitting here with Bartley, and he a baby, lying on my two knees, and I saw two women, and three women, and four women coming in, and they crossing themselves, and not saying a word. . . I looked out then, and there were men coming after them, and they holding a thing in the half of a red sail, and water dripping out of it -- it was a dry day, Nora -- and leaving a track to the door.
sp.stage: (She pauses again with her hand stretched out towards the door. It opens softly and old women begin to come in, crossing themselves on the threshold, audand kneeling down in front of the stage with their backs to the people, and the white waist-bands of the red petticoats they wear over their heads just seen from behind).

sp.speaker: Maurya
sp.p: Is it Patch, or Michael, or what is it at all?

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: Michael is after being found in the far north, and when he is found there how could he be here in this place?

sp.speaker: Maurya
sp.p: There does be a power of young men ﬂoating round in the sea, and what way would they know if it was Michael they had, or another man like him, for when a man is nine days in the sea, and a wind blowing, it's hard set his own mother would be to say what man was in it.

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p:
It’s Michael, God spare him, for they're after sending us
a bit of his clothes from the far north.
sp.stage: (She reaches out and hands Maurya the clothes that belonged to Michael. Maurya stands up slowly, and takes them in her hands. . . Nora looks out.)

sp.speaker: Nora
sp.p: They're carrying a thing among them and there's water dripping out of it and leaving a track by the big stones. . .

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.stage: (in a whisper to the women who have come in.)
sp.p: It is Bartley it is?

sp.speaker: One of the Women
sp.p: It is surely, God rest his soul.

div.stage: (Two younger women come in and pull out the table. Then men carry in the body of Bartley, laid on a plank, with a bit of a sail over it, and lay it on the table.)

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.stage: (to the women, as they are doing so.)
sp.p: What way was he drowned?

sp.speaker: One of the Women
sp.p: The grey pony knocked him over into the sea, and he was washed out where there is a great surf on the white rocks.

div.stage: (Maurya has gone over and knelt down at the head of the table. The women are keening softly and swaying themselves with a slow movement. Cathleen and Nora kneel at the other end of the table. The men kneel near the door.)

sp.speaker: Maurya
sp.stage: (raising her head and speaking as if she did not see the people round her.
sp.p: They're all gone now, and there isn't anything more the sea can do to me. . . . I'll have no call now to be up crying and praying when the wind breaks from the south, and you can hear the surf is in the east, and the surf is in the west, making a great stir with the two noises, and they hitting one on the other. I'll have no call now to be going down and getting Holy Water in the dark nights after Samhain, and I won't care what way the sea is when the other women will be keening. . .
Give me the Holy Water, Nora, there's a small sup still on the dresser.

sp.speaker: Maurya
sp.stage: (drops Michael's clothes across Bartley's feet, and sprinkles the Holy Water over him)
sp.p: It isn't that I haven't prayed for you, Bartley, to the Almighty God. It isn't that I haven't said prayers in the dark night till you wouldn't know what I'ld be saying; but it's a great rest I'll have now, and it's time surely . . It's a great rest I'll have now, and great sleeping in the long nights after Samhain, if it's only a bit of wet ﬂour we do have to eat, and maybe a fish that would be stinking.
sp.stage: (She kneels down again, crossing herself, and saying prayers under her breath).

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: Maybe yourself and Eamon would make a coffin when the sun rises. We have ﬁne white boards herself bought, God help her, thinking Michael would be found, and I have a new cake you can eat while you'll be working.

sp.speaker: The Man
sp.p: Are there nails with them?

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: There are not, Colum; we didn’t think of the nails.

sp.speaker: Another Man
sp.p: It's a great wonder she wouldn't think of the nails, and all the coﬁins she's seen made already.

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: It's getting old she is and broken.

div.stage: Maurya stands up again very slowly and spreads out the pieces of Michael's clothes beside the body, sprinkling them with the last of the Holy Water.

sp.speaker: Nora
sp.p: She's quiet now and easy; but the day Michael was drowned you could hear her crying out from this to the spring well. It's fonder she was of Michael, and would anyone have thought that?

sp.speaker: Cathleen
sp.p: An old woman will be soon tired with anything she will do, and isn't it nine days herself is after crying, and keening, and making great sorrow in the house?

sp.speaker: Maurya
sp.stage: (puts the empty cup mouth downwards on the table, and lays her hands together on Bartley's feet)
sp.p: They're all together this time, and the end is come. May the Almighty God have mercy on Bart1ey's soul, and on Michael's soul, and on the souls of Sheamus, and Patch, and Stephen, and Shawn (bending her head); and may He have mercy on my soul, Nora, and on the soul of everyone is left living in the world (she pauses, and the keen rises a little more loudly from the women, then sinks away).

sp.speaker: Maurya
sp.p: Michael has a clean burial in the far north, by the grace of the Almighty God. Bartley will have a ﬁne cofﬁn out of the white boards, and a deep grave surely. What more can we want than that? No man at all can be living for ever, and we must be satisﬁed.
sp.stage: (She kneels down again and the curtain falls slowly).
